title: Judges Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Judges chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Judges Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Judges Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who did the LORD say should go up first to fight against the Canaanites?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:2 states that the LORD said Judah shall go up first.

questions.question: What did Judah say to Simeon regarding the fight against the Canaanites?
options: Come with me into my lot, and I will come with thee into thy lot
Let us wait for the others to join
We should not fight without God's direct command
We should go separately to cover more ground
questions.correctAnswer: Come with me into my lot, and I will come with thee into thy lot
questions.explanation: Judges 1:3 records Judah inviting Simeon to come with him into his lot and promising to go with him into his lot.

questions.question: How many men did Judah and Simeon kill in Bezek?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:4 states they slew ten thousand men in Bezek.

questions.question: What happened to Adonibezek after he was captured?
options: His thumbs and great toes were cut off
questions.correctAnswer: His thumbs and great toes were cut off
questions.explanation: Judges 1:6 tells how they caught Adonibezek and cut off his thumbs and great toes.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 1:8, the children of Judah set Jerusalem on fire after taking it.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:8 says Judah took Jerusalem, smote it with the sword, and set the city on fire.

questions.question: Who did Caleb promise his daughter Achsah to if they captured Kirjathsepher?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:12 records Caleb saying whoever smites Kirjathsepher and takes it will receive Achsah as wife.

questions.question: Who was given Achsah in marriage after capturing Kirjathsepher?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:13 states Othniel, Caleb's younger brother, took Kirjathsepher and was given Achsah in marriage.

questions.question: What additional blessing did Achsah ask her father Caleb for?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:15 relates that Achsah asked Caleb for springs of water, which he gave her.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD was with the house of Joseph when they went against Bethel.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:22 confirms that the LORD was with the house of Joseph in their attack on Bethel.

questions.question: What was the original name of the city Bethel?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:23 says the name of Bethel before was Luz.

questions.question: What did the man from Bethel do after showing the spies the entrance into the city?
options: He went into the land of the Hittites and built a city
He was killed with his family
He led the spies to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He went into the land of the Hittites and built a city
questions.explanation: Judges 1:26 states the man went into the land of the Hittites and built a city named Luz.

questions.question: Which tribe did NOT drive out the Jebusites from Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:21 states that the children of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites who lived in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: The Canaanites dwelling in the valley were driven out by Judah.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:19 says Judah could not drive out the inhabitants of the valley because they had chariots of iron.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: After the death of Joshua, the children of Israel asked the LORD, saying, 'Who shall go up for us against the ______ first, to fight against them?'
questions.explanation: Judges 1:1 records the children of Israel asking who shall go up against the Canaanites first.

questions.question: Which city did Judah and Simeon utterly destroy, renaming it Hormah?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:17 states Judah and Simeon slew the Canaanites in Zephath and called the city Hormah.

medium.title: Judges Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Judges Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of facing challenges. Based on Judges 1:1-4, what biblical truth about faith and trust in God would you share?
options: God delivers the land into the hands of those who obey and trust Him.
Success depends only on our own strength and weapons.
We should avoid battles and conflicts to stay safe.
God is indifferent to the struggles we face.
questions.correctAnswer: God delivers the land into the hands of those who obey and trust Him.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:2-4 shows that the LORD told Judah to go up first and delivered the Canaanites and Perizzites into their hands, demonstrating that trusting God leads to victory in challenges.

questions.question: How does the story of Adonibezek in Judges 1:5-7 teach us about humility and God's justice?
options: God repays us according to our actions, so humility is vital.
Power and pride guarantee success and favor from God.
Revenge is the best way to deal with enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: God repays us according to our actions, so humility is vital.
questions.explanation: Adonibezek's mutilation and words in Judges 1:6-7 illustrate that God requites men as they have done, teaching humility and accountability before God.

questions.question: A believer is seeking guidance on working together in church fellowship. What lesson can be drawn from Judah inviting Simeon to fight with him in Judges 1:3?
options: Collaborating with others strengthens efforts and achieves God’s purposes.
Working alone is the best way to serve God.
Only leaders should be involved in important tasks.
questions.correctAnswer: Collaborating with others strengthens efforts and achieves God’s purposes.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:3 describes Judah asking Simeon to join him, showing that unity and cooperation are important in accomplishing God’s work.

questions.question: Considering Judges 1:12-15, how does this passage teach us about marriage and family blessings?
options: Marriage can be a source of spiritual and material blessings when founded on faith.
Marriage is only about personal preference without spiritual significance.
Family blessings are unrelated to obedience and faith.
Marriage should be avoided to focus on spiritual matters.
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage can be a source of spiritual and material blessings when founded on faith.
questions.explanation: Caleb’s promise to give his daughter Achsah as a wife (Judges 1:12-13) and her request for springs of water (verses 14-15) demonstrate blessings in marriage when faith and wise requests align.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel unable to overcome certain struggles. How does Judges 1:19 and 1:29-33 encourage perseverance and contentment?
options: Even when complete victory is not achieved, God’s presence allows for peace and provision.
Partial failure means God has abandoned you.
You should give up if obstacles remain.
Victory is only physical and immediate.
questions.correctAnswer: Even when complete victory is not achieved, God’s presence allows for peace and provision.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:19 and 1:29-33 show that some inhabitants were not driven out but became tributaries, indicating God’s provision despite incomplete conquest, teaching perseverance and contentment.

questions.question: How does the example of the spies in Judges 1:23-26 teach us about integrity and mercy in difficult situations?
options: Showing mercy to those who help us reflects God’s grace and promotes peace.
We should not trust anyone outside our group.
Mercy is a sign of weakness in conflict.
Integrity means avoiding all interactions with enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: Showing mercy to those who help us reflects God’s grace and promotes peace.
questions.explanation: In Judges 1:24-26, the spies spared the man and his family who showed them the city entrance, highlighting mercy and integrity even in conflict.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by spiritual battles. Based on Judges 1:20, what truth about God’s faithfulness and our inheritance can you share?
options: God gives us victory and inheritance when we trust and obey Him.
Spiritual battles are impossible to win.
Our inheritance depends solely on our effort without God’s help.
God abandons us when challenges arise.
questions.correctAnswer: God gives us victory and inheritance when we trust and obey Him.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:20 shows Caleb receiving Hebron and expelling foes as Moses had promised, illustrating God’s faithfulness to those who trust Him.

questions.question: True or False: According to Judges 1:21, the children of Benjamin completely drove out the Jebusites from Jerusalem.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:21 states that the children of Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites, who dwelt with them in Jerusalem to this day.

questions.question: How does the account of the Kenites joining the children of Judah in Judges 1:16 teach us about fellowship and support in service to God?
options: Joining together in community strengthens our walk and service to God.
Isolation is preferable for spiritual growth.
Only one tribe should serve God at a time.
questions.correctAnswer: Joining together in community strengthens our walk and service to God.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:16 shows the Kenites leaving their city to dwell with Judah, demonstrating the strength found in fellowship and shared service.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to become proud of their achievements. What lesson on humility is taught through Adonibezek’s story in Judges 1:6-7?
options: God humbles the proud by repaying according to their deeds.
Pride leads to lasting honor and success.
questions.correctAnswer: God humbles the proud by repaying according to their deeds.
questions.explanation: Adonibezek’s capture and mutilation (Judges 1:6-7) illustrate that God’s justice humbles the proud, encouraging believers to remain humble.

questions.question: True or False: Judges 1:28 teaches that when Israel grew strong, they completely drove out all the Canaanites without exception.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:28 states that Israel put the Canaanites to tribute but did not utterly drive them out, showing partial victory with ongoing challenges.

questions.question: How does Caleb’s gift to Achsah in Judges 1:15 teach us about generosity and stewardship in family life?
options: Generosity in family blessings includes providing for both needs and spiritual well-being.
Family provision should focus only on material wealth.
Stewardship means limiting blessings to what is absolutely necessary.
Marriage gifts are unimportant in family life.
questions.correctAnswer: Generosity in family blessings includes providing for both needs and spiritual well-being.
questions.explanation: Caleb granting Achsah springs of water (Judges 1:15) shows generous stewardship meeting needs, teaching believers to bless family abundantly.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by partial success in their work for God. Based on Judges 1:18-19, what encouragement can you offer about God’s presence during challenges?
options: God’s presence is with us even if we cannot completely overcome every obstacle.
We should quit if success is not immediate.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s presence is with us even if we cannot completely overcome every obstacle.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:18-19 shows that the LORD was with Judah and they drove out many inhabitants, but some remained due to chariots of iron, illustrating God’s continued presence amid difficulties.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Judges 1:17 tells us that Judah and Simeon slew the Canaanites that inhabited Zephath, and the city was called ___.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:17 states that after Judah and Simeon destroyed Zephath, the city was called Hormah, teaching obedience in carrying out God’s commands.

questions.question: How does the story of the house of Joseph capturing Bethel in Judges 1:22-26 teach about reliance on God's guidance and mercy in evangelism and service?
options: Relying on God’s guidance leads to successful missions combined with mercy toward those who help us.
Mercy should be withheld to maintain power.
questions.correctAnswer: Relying on God’s guidance leads to successful missions combined with mercy toward those who help us.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:22-26 shows that the house of Joseph was successful with the LORD’s help and spared a man and his family who assisted them, illustrating reliance on God and mercy.

hard.title: Judges Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Judges Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who did the LORD command to go up first against the Canaanites after Joshua's death?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:2 states the LORD said Judah shall go up first against the Canaanites.

questions.question: What significant act of cruelty did the Israelites inflict on Adonibezek after capturing him?
options: Cut off his thumbs and great toes
questions.correctAnswer: Cut off his thumbs and great toes
questions.explanation: Judges 1:6 describes how they cut off Adonibezek's thumbs and great toes as retribution.

questions.question: Which city did Judah and Simeon utterly destroy and rename Hormah?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:17 records that Judah and Simeon destroyed Zephath and called it Hormah.

questions.question: Who was given Achsah's hand in marriage after capturing Kirjathsepher?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:13 states Othniel, Caleb's younger brother, took Kirjathsepher and married Achsah.

questions.question: What additional blessing did Achsah request from her father Caleb after marriage?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:15 recounts Achsah’s request for springs of water, which Caleb granted.

questions.question: Why were the children of Judah unable to drive out the inhabitants of the valley?
options: The inhabitants had chariots of iron
They were too few in number
questions.correctAnswer: The inhabitants had chariots of iron
questions.explanation: Judges 1:19 specifies that the Canaanites’ iron chariots prevented Judah from driving them out.

questions.question: Which tribe did not drive out the Jebusites from Jerusalem and lived alongside them?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:21 indicates that Benjamin did not drive out the Jebusites, who dwelt with them.

questions.question: What is the significance of the man who showed the spies the entrance to Bethel in terms of covenant mercy?
options: He was spared along with his family
questions.correctAnswer: He was spared along with his family
questions.explanation: Judges 1:25 explains that because he showed mercy, the man and his family were let go.

questions.question: The renaming of Luz after the man built a city there is an example of which literary device?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:26 shows the man naming the city Luz after himself, a classic eponymous naming device.

questions.question: Which tribe did not drive out the Canaanites dwelling in Gezer, resulting in coexistence?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:29 states Ephraim did not drive out the Canaanites in Gezer, leading to coexistence.

questions.question: What is the cultural or historical significance of cutting off thumbs and great toes, as done to Adonibezek?
options: It disabled his ability to fight and hold a weapon
It was a ritual for kingship
It was a sign of blessing
It was to make him immortal
questions.correctAnswer: It disabled his ability to fight and hold a weapon
questions.explanation: Removing thumbs and great toes crippled a warrior’s ability to fight, which was a form of divine justice noted in Judges 1:6-7.

questions.question: The alliance of Judah and Simeon in conquering Canaanite cities demonstrates what theme prevalent throughout Judges?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:3 and 1:17 illustrate cooperation between tribes Judah and Simeon for conquest.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the narrative structure of Judges chapter 1?
questions.explanation: Judges 1 recounts the step-by-step military actions of Israelite tribes after Joshua’s death.

questions.question: True or False: The children of Dan were able to settle freely in the valley without conflict from the Amorites.
questions.explanation: Judges 1:34 states the Amorites forced Dan into the mountain, preventing valley settlement.

questions.question: The mention of 'chariots of iron' in Judges 1:19 reflects what historical reality about Canaanite military technology?
options: Use of bow and arrow exclusively
questions.explanation: The 'chariots of iron' indicate advanced military technology that Israelite tribes struggled against.

questions.question: Which tribe's failure to fully drive out the Canaanites resulted in the Canaanites becoming tributaries rather than being destroyed?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:30 states Zebulun did not drive out Canaanites but made them tributaries.

theological.title: Judges Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Judges Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who did the LORD designate to go up first against the Canaanites after Joshua's death?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:2 states that the LORD said Judah shall go up first. This shows God's sovereign guidance in battle (Exodus 23:23, Joshua 10:1, Psalm 44:3, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What was the consequence for Adonibezek after he was captured?
options: His thumbs and great toes were cut off
questions.correctAnswer: His thumbs and great toes were cut off
questions.explanation: Judges 1:6 describes that Adonibezek had his thumbs and great toes cut off, reflecting divine justice as he had done the same to others (Leviticus 24:20, Proverbs 24:17-18, Romans 12:19, Revelation 20:12).

questions.question: Which city did the children of Judah take and set on fire?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:8 records that Judah took Jerusalem and set it on fire, showing the conquest phase of the promised land (Deuteronomy 7:1-2, Joshua 6:21, 1 Kings 11:13, Revelation 21:9-10).

questions.question: Who was given Achsah's hand in marriage upon capturing Kirjathsepher (Debir)?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:13 shows Caleb gave his daughter Achsah to Othniel for capturing Debir, illustrating covenant faithfulness and leadership succession (Genesis 24:58, Ruth 4:13, 1 Samuel 18:25, Ephesians 5:25).

questions.question: What did Achsah request from her father Caleb after marriage?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:15 records Achsah asking for springs of water, symbolizing blessing and provision, consistent with God’s provision in Scripture (Isaiah 58:11, John 4:14, Psalm 1:3, Revelation 22:1).

questions.question: Why could Judah not drive out the inhabitants of the valley?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:19 explains the inability due to iron chariots, showing the challenge of incomplete obedience and trust in God (Joshua 17:16-18, Deuteronomy 20:1-4, Psalm 20:7, 2 Chronicles 17:12).

questions.question: Which tribe did not drive out the Jebusites from Jerusalem?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:21 states Benjamin did not drive out Jebusites, indicating incomplete conquest and coexistence with sin, foreshadowing future conflict (Joshua 15:63, 1 Kings 11:7, Ezra 9:1-2, Romans 12:2).

questions.question: What was the former name of Bethel before it was taken by the house of Joseph?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:23 identifies Bethel’s former name as Luz, connecting to God's covenantal promises and theophanies (Genesis 28:19, Joshua 18:13, Hebrews 11:9-10, Revelation 21:2).

questions.question: What did the spies promise the man from Luz if he showed them the entrance into the city?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:24 reveals the promise of mercy, illustrating faithfulness to promises and God’s justice (Exodus 20:16, Psalm 15:4, Matthew 5:7, Romans 12:17).

questions.question: How did the man from Luz respond after the city was captured?
options: He went to the land of the Hittites and built a city called Luz
questions.correctAnswer: He went to the land of the Hittites and built a city called Luz
questions.explanation: Judges 1:26 shows the man relocating and rebuilding, reflecting themes of exile and restoration (Genesis 15:13-16, Jeremiah 29:4-7, Psalm 137:1-4, Revelation 21:2).

questions.question: Which tribes did not drive out the Canaanites but allowed them to dwell among them?
questions.explanation: Judges 1:27-33 describes multiple tribes failing to fully drive out Canaanites, highlighting human disobedience and syncretism, which led to future judgment (Exodus 34:12-16, Judges 2:2-3, 1 Kings 11:1-8, 2 Kings 17:7-23).

questions.question: What does the partial conquest and coexistence with Canaanites teach about Israel’s obedience to God’s commands?
options: Incomplete obedience leads to ongoing struggle and judgment
God does not require full obedience
Coexistence was a sign of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Incomplete obedience leads to ongoing struggle and judgment
questions.explanation: The chapter’s record (Judges 1:27-33) demonstrates that Israel’s failure to fully obey God’s command to drive out the Canaanites led to persistent conflict and idolatry (Deuteronomy 7:2-3, Judges 2:1-3, Hebrews 10:26-31, Romans 6:16).

questions.question: What does the presence of the LORD with Judah during battles signify about God’s attribute?
options: God’s faithfulness and presence in His covenant people’s endeavors
God is distant from human affairs
Victory comes by human strength only
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness and presence in His covenant people’s endeavors
questions.explanation: Judges 1:19 and 22 note the LORD was with Judah and Joseph, illustrating God’s covenant faithfulness and active presence in history (Exodus 33:14, Psalm 46:7, Matthew 28:20, Hebrews 13:5).

questions.question: Who were the Kenites, and what was their relationship with the children of Judah?
options: Relatives of Moses who dwelt with Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Relatives of Moses who dwelt with Judah
questions.explanation: Judges 1:16 states the Kenites were Moses' father-in-law's descendants who lived with Judah, showing God's providential preservation of faithful families and unity within God’s people (Exodus 18:1-6, Numbers 10:29-32, Judges 4:11, Luke 1:50).

questions.question: What theological lesson can be drawn from the recurring theme of 'the LORD was with' in the conquests?
options: Victory depends on divine presence and blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Victory depends on divine presence and blessing
questions.explanation: The phrase highlights God’s sovereignty and grace as decisive in victory, consistent with biblical teaching on God’s providence (Judges 1:19, Joshua 1:5, Psalm 44:3, 1 Corinthians 15:57).
